title: Dermatomyositis in a Middle-Aged Woman Presenting with Proximal Muscle Weakness
clinical_history: Mrs. Deborah L., a 47-year-old accountant, presents to the outpatient physical therapy clinic with complaints of progressively worsening weakness in her proximal muscles over the last 3 months. She notes difficulty in rising from chairs, climbing stairs, and lifting her arms overhead to wash her hair or reach high shelves. She first noticed increasing muscle fatigue after a weekend hiking trip, where she struggled to keep pace with her friends. In the past month, she developed a reddish-purple rash on her upper eyelids and over the knuckles of both hands. She reports mild pain but primarily describes profound muscle fatigue. No previous similar episodes. No trauma reported. She experiences morning stiffness, but it tends to improve slightly as the day progresses. She continues to work but has scaled back physical activities and relies on her husband for household chores.

nprs.affected_area: bilateral proximal muscles of shoulders and hips (deltoids, gluteals, quadriceps)
distal musculature, e.g., hands (minor aching, primarily related to rash/skin over MCP joints)

aggrevating_factors: Sustained or repeated overhead activities, climbing stairs, transitioning from sit to stand, walking uphill, prolonged standing, fatigue worsens with high ambient temperatures.
picture: [insert image depicting characteristic heliotrope rash on eyelids and Gottron's papules on knuckles, with highlighting of proximal muscle groups]
easing_factors: Rest, gentle stretching; mild improvement with cool compresses over affected skin areas.
past_history: Unremarkable; no prior major illnesses, musculoskeletal injuries, or autoimmune conditions. Childhood vaccinations up to date. No history of recent infections.
medical_history: Seasonal allergic rhinitis. No diabetes, hypertension, or prior cardiac/cerebrovascular issues. No family history of autoimmune disease.
medications: Prednisone 30mg daily (starting 1 week ago), topical corticosteroid cream for hand rash, loratadine 10mg prn for allergies.
personal_history: Non-smoker, minimal alcohol intake, exercises occasionally (walking), married, one teenage son. Reports moderate stress at work and home due to new physical limitations and self-consciousness about her skin changes.
imaging: MRI of proximal thighs: symmetrical muscle edema suggestive of inflammatory myopathy. EMG ordered but results pending.
